title: Before 1 January 2020, will the U.S. President sign legislation increasing the number of exemptions for autonomous vehicles allowed per manufacturer by the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards?
preds: Dropping a few points to zero because there's only a few weeks left in the year.
Dropping because of passage of time and, well, DC is busy with some other things at the moment.
This would require Congress to pass a piece of substantive legislation in the next couple of months.  If this were a joke, it would be a very funny one indeed.
I don't see an incentive for the administration to spend time on this.
Time update due to the tariffs that President Trump enacted.
update for passage of time, and comments from other forecasters.

Reading the thread is better than reading the tea leaves. Lots of good insights. 
But what is Congress' motivation - they cannot agree on simple things the country needs, how can they finesse something this complex with no immediate payback and lots of risk to those approving. I'll bump my estimate just to be non-zero.
Thank you @cafebedouin. people with small hands probably like the thought of cars driving themselves...  does have bipartisan support so maybe...

Coming back up to 65%. Looks like Senate has this as a priority this go around.
https://thehill.com/policy/transportation/444097-senate-commerce-chair-to-renew-push-for-regs-on-self-driving-vehicles

"Donald Trump has aligned himself with the 71 percent of Americans wary of self-driving cars, reportedly telling a number of people he doesn’t trust autonomous vehicle tech, according to Axios." Based on this, and that Trump tends to follow through on his convictions, there is a very low likelihood (7%) that Trump would sign this.

OUTSIDE CASE "Before a bill becomes a law it must pass both houses of Congress and signed into law by the President. It may begin its journey at any time, but it must be passed during the same congressional session of its proposal, a period of one year. If it does not complete the process, it is dropped, and can only be revived through reintroduction and going through the whole process again. Not surprisingly, less that 10% of proposed bills actually become laws." [1] Simplistically 10% pro rata the 7 months of the year remaining gives 6%. (This might be a very dubious methodology.) INSIDE CASE Snippet from The Hill article - 6th May 2019 [2];
--------------------------------------------------------------
The AV START Act could face some of the same objections from Senate Democrats as it did last time, however.   Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.), one of the five senators who held up consideration of the legislation in the Senate last Congress, told The Hill last week that while he didn’t oppose the bill last year, “I insisted on certain provisions that would protect safety.” When asked if he was working with Thune to address those provisions, Blumenthal said, “not yet, we may well, he knows about my concerns, so does Sen. Peters, and they haven’t changed.”

Increasing my forecast a bit since there is concrete movement: https://thehill.com/policy/transportation/444097-senate-commerce-chair-to-renew-push-for-regs-on-self-driving-vehicles
Starting to think Congress is going to have its hands full with other business.
Trump is reportedly terrified of driverless cars, so this is unlikely unless there is some kind of jobs bill attached to it. https://futurism.com/donald-trump-trust-autonomous-cars

- Base rate for a bill getting passed seems about 4%. [1] (Does somebody have more recent numbers?)
- Both bills died in the last Congress (both in the Senate if I'm reading this correctly). [2] [3]
- John Thune and Bob Latta, the two authors are still in Congress. Their legislative effectiveness scores are high from what I can tell: 3.169 (Thune), 2.687 (Latta).
- The House bill had 31 co-sponsors and was bi-partisan [4] The Senate bill had four co-sponsors and was also bi-partisan. [5] 
- The composition of the US Senate did not change significantly since the last bills died.
My informed guess is that such a bill will pass with a chance of 17% chance this year. Will Trump sign it? I couldn't find any base rates for this. I'd guess it's pretty high. Perhaps 90%? Is this totally off? That would give 15%. [1] https://www.huffpost.com/entry/the-vast-majority-of-bill_n_268630

Dropping 10 points because I don't see anything getting done this year in DC.
Money to be made and it's in the works already.
Trump would not want to lose out to China on AVs, not after getting surpassed in 5G by China
Trump does not approve autonomous vehicles.
With Tesla's increasing market share it is inevitable

Waiting for more info before adjusting.
With GM and Ford betting heavily on ride hailing AVs, and Waymo already there, that is a huge force to get this done!
Adjusting down to move towards the crowd forecast somewhat. Also, with the Mueller report likely to come out soon, Congress might be occupied with that.
Sel driving cars are great for people with small hands but not sure this will see light of day (I recall no promises - even tangentially related).
The real issue with autonomous vehicles is not regulators. The technology is what is prohibiting federal deployment.

It needs to get done. Much of it could be done on a regulatory level. Still, I'm staying on the plus side because as Waymo starts building a factory for autonomous vehicles, GM's and Kroger's delivery services, etc., it's going to get momentum. https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/new-congress-looks-at-driverless-cars
no one's running under the election slogan: "make truckers unemployed"
I am going with wisdom of the crowds. The Crowd is within the interval I got when I evaluated the evidence at https://www.getguesstimate.com/models/12508.

Forecasting this is like rearranging the deck chairs. Look over there people!  
We have a dysfunctional government and have abused every friend and institution we had. 
Do you want fries with that?
US Congress in no shape for sheparding lesser special interests. Trump/White House will have their hands full as well.

Automakers are need of more data, not vehicle modifications. I think the Bill was introduced as a way for the Michigan Senators to show that they are on the Manufacturers good side. Vehicular Modification is not an issue car manufacturers often come into and it'd be very hard for me to conceive a world where Congress passes a bill to problem that has not yet occurred. In addition, this is a bipartisan bill and as we have seen from the current administration is not about bi-partisanship, rather how can I show my power over other branches.

There is no chance that the President will wish to benefit a state with 2 Democratic senators (MI). Currently, he has disagreements with automakers and his base is anti-autonomous vehicles.  In addition, progressives feel that there are insufficient consumer protections.
The current occupant of the White House will sign anything his party puts in front of him and has shown that he has no qualms about placing consumers (citizens, etc.) under undue risk

If legislation passes both chambers and if he gets the okey-dokey from his puppetmasters at both Fox News and the Saudi Crown Prince, he may clutch a pen in his tiny little fingers and sign such a bill, unless for example the bill's opponents throw a very large and lucrative convention at one of his properties.   Strange days.

I think the US President - and indeed, the legislature - has other problems at the moment and playing nice with the auto industry is not top of the agenda. Getting anything through even after the shutdown will be a tight timescale. However, if Ford/GM 'bring some jobs home' this could be a quid pro quo to assist them in seeing off Lyft/Waymo/VW and the others.
I think the President likes deregulation and supporting auto makers.  If they want this, they will probably get it.   it also depends how often he is distracted by the Wall and Fox and Friends.
Trump is on the side of car companies, and this is what they want.

Technology is rapidly improving and there are several industries that have interests in seeing this technology advance.  These interests will combine to form an influential body in regulation.  The main threat to this is the potential for having several high profile mishaps.

Barring bad timing of another fatal crash, I give it a bit over 50% chance, as compromises are being worked out. But only slightly over. AVs are sliding down into the trough of despair on the Gartner curve, and test deployment pace slowing.
This president and self driving cars? Nah...
there are still to many glitches with the technology.
No way. Not this guy. Not technology
Trump will give the auto sector what it wants.
Business pressure on our government always wins
Current administration great deregulator. I have no trust in current administration to make informed choice
Any thing that dampens global oil production is anethma to this administration

They have to start again, but despite the pessimism that they'll do t this year, I think there will be pressure to make the rules across states more uniform from the companies doing it. Sticking with more likely than not.

If this looks like it will make it through both chambers, rest assured someone (at least one) will try to attach a rider that the other side will hate, and after enough riders from both sides that are equally disliked, this will likely tank. Assuming that doesn't happen, and it reaches the president, it's still dicey as to whether he actually signs it.  It would be interesting to see if him not signing and allowing it to become law after the 10 day period would resolve this question as a yes.
Stupidly yet again I made a forecast without knowing anything at all. So I'm going to track the crowd until I can develop my own view on this question.
It looks to me like all heck will break loose on Capital Hill. Those self-driving vehicle lobbyists will find long lines at every door to power.
The Congress may well pass something like this, but it is difficult to know what will happen when it hits 1600 until Tox News instructs The Current Incumbent.
The President will see this as an opportunity to advance new tech jobs andsecodarily to appease the environmentalists.
I serious doubt it because of the negative effects electric cars are having on old industry
This administration will always lean toward more autonomy and less regulation for business entities.
Correcting down because of passage of time
Lots of interest by car makers in this area, waymonis making progress and the NTSA seems pro-autonomous vehicle. Politics in Washington are messy now but this could be bipartisan.
Focus of the currenr government is on other industries. No priority for new technologies.
I don't like betting on US federal government doing stuff
Too many variables to be confident. Guessing
Congress will be afraid of too rapid implementation of this technology.
Trump doesn’t like electric cars, and he is down on GM who would be helped by this. Not sure who is pushing this. It would help Tesla.

No not after the GM bait and switch.
Post #2 , 
I do not think this will be and easy answer we need testing the only way government help.

In the Department of Transportations, "Automated Vehicles 3.0: Preparing for the Future of Transportation 3.0." published October 4, 2018 it states one of its objectives: "Modernize regulations as existing Federal regulations and standards may pose challenges to the widespread integration of automated vehicles. U.S. DOT developed many of its regulations over a period of decades, generally with the assumption that a human driver would always be present. U.S. DOT is in the process of identifying and modifying regulations that unnecessarily impede the testing, sale, operation, or use of automation across the surface transportation system."[1] So, one question is whether legislation is even necessary. This might be more a question of rewriting regulations. On the other hand, there seems to be a good idea of progression where this is going to be required for better safety, as can be seen in the following report. Coming down a little, but still think it is more likely than not.
https://www.nhtsa.gov/technology-innovation/automated-vehicles
Tough to say. Truck drivers and delivery drivers are his base. He may wait until a second term for this kind of thing.

Seems unlikely, I figured this would happen the last time the question was asked and I don't want to get burned again. Plus I kinda get the feeling that the next year is going to spent almost entirely on fighting between parties.
The increasing demand coupled with greater 2020 GOP reelection support from lobbyist should make this happen.

This is probably not going to rise above the static of the next year. In the coming month, the CR expires Dec 7, so Congress will have to pass a budget or kick the can with another CR. Based on the last 20 years, they will likely pass another short-term CR until about Jan 18 (MLK Day is Jan 21, so it buys Congress an extra 3 days with minimal impact in case they can't pass a budget or CR). Looking back and doing the calculations my self, the average CR length is 110 days (excluding 3 years with full-year CRs - including that data increases the CR length to 140 days). Conveniently, 110 days this year falls on Friday, Jan 18. So there's that. Putting the budget debacle aside, once Dems come into power in the House, they are likely to begin using their subpoena power rather quickly. They'll probably not go directly after Trump right out the gate, but will likely strike close enough to cause the President to react, which will then probably cause an escalation by both sides. The partisan rancor caused by this will likely kill off all but the most benign of bipartisan bills as each side will likely view with suspicion anything that helps the other. Congress will have roughly 7 months (the end of July) to get this legislation passed before going back into the budget debacle post-August recess. If it's not signed by July, the likelihood that it gets approved decreases as the pressure mounts on Congress and the WH to keep the government operational again. Perhaps an overly pessimistic view, but this should've been an easy win last year and was not. Now moving forward with a divided government, its hard to see how this remains an easy win.

I agree with @patrickmeehan5 's point about an easy bi-partisan gesture. So I think there will be an increase in the exemptions at some point, so the key to the question is whether it will happen in the specified time frame.
https://www.quora.com/How-long-does-it-take-to-pass-a-bill-in-the-US
Although the top answer here is right to state that there are of course very diverse reasons why some bills take longer or don't pass into law at all, the median and average times it took from introduction to becoming law are less than a year (215 and 263 days, respectively). Since this bill has been around for some time and has some support, I think it is fairly likely it will become a law in the specified timeframe.

This is a bill the House Dems support in general and it would be an easy bi-partisan gesture to make for both the Senate to pass and the President to sign.  The September House bill passed unanimously and all of the major automakers are investing heavily in the technology and are already siren-calling "jobs" and "manufacturing" that all politicians love to hear.

He may spout to his fanboys about being against progress, but he will support anything that will make himself and his cronies richer at the expense of the people.
